Start a new game

_____________________

This game is terrible, I feel almost ashamed that I even own this. Its being way too kind to call this shovelware, since that would seem to imply that some kind of tool or implement was used to dump this pile of crap onto Steam.

The game can't barely even hit 30 fps on the lowest setings and mostly runs at 20-25 fps, very poorly optimized. The dev got this game through greenlight through bribing people with free keys.

The graphics don't seem to reflect the difficulty of trying to get this game just to hit 30 fps, games either need to have good graphics or a good aesthetics. Blood of Old has neither.

The menus look dull and scream of default unity GUI. The animations are terrible and look almost nothing like what they're trying to be. Items are difficult to pick up at times and the combat is one dimmensional at best.

I can see the 'developers' vision when making this game, but this guy has clearly taken on a project too big for himself. I'd recommend Mount and Blade Warband over this game, if you want to be a warrior starting from the bottom and becoming a vassal or king with your own castle. Then thats probably a better game for you, it also has mod support, multiplayer and trading cards. If you get it on sale you may get a better deal than buying Blood of Old at full price.

The 'dev' has now added trading cards try and get some positive reviews, this reflects a larger issue on Steam. That people will actually rate a bad game positively due to trading cards, its unfortunate.

People seem to try and defend this game, saying its not a AAA game or that its in early access or that its made by an indie developer.

These excuses are just not valid. Have some standards and release something worth showing. I'd feel cheated if I spent a single penny on this, luckily I did not.

Early Access Review

I worry about the well-fare of developers like this. I can understand your dream, you 19 year old, you, but at this point I feel like flat-out development is beyond reach for you. I don't mean to not keep trying, but maybe consider getting better before you release something for real money on the market.

As for the rest of you, and the developer, I suppose, if he reads through this, this is my experience with the game:

I spawned in a jail-cell without context. It looked... meh, about on par with a vanilla, original release, Mount and Blade. I worked through it, finding, to my surprise that everything worked, with some minor inconveneince as I discovered that chains came with a forcefield. No worries, I suppose that it *is* in an alpha build, and collision boxes will possibly be refined.

So, once out of that, I immediately began grabbing all of the things, which is where things began going wrong, the ability to pick things up breaking after a moment and never being able to be used again with exception to the rusty sword and shield.

I was then engaged in intense, mortal combat with the nearest enemy, and at first, I thought I couldn't attack, possibly because I was out of stamina, which never seems to regenerate. However, it was just that the animation for attacks rarely plays, and I was actually doing damage- sometimes. Anyway, I ran around the camp, the enemy not able to deal with my combat prowress as it chased after me, and, finding it empty, I ran on to the first location.

While exploring the land, I found the following wonders:

1) A pig model with no pig AI
2) A completely empty village
3) Armies of clones of a man who seemed to enjoy wearing a  skull
4) A pond that allowed any mortal man to ascend to the level of Jesus, and walk upon it's pure, blue, surfaces
5) A deer that can do the same
6) Sudden day-night cycles, with night doing nothing to change the ambient light levels, and lasting a fraction of the the day.

So, I finally reached our first objective, the walled city of Completely-forgettable, and proceeded to do the following things:

1) Push the horse cart around, because it's model is apparently not fixed and you can just push it around as muchas you want
2) Hire an underling to discover that the command system does not work.
3) Talk to the commander, get a new mission, and proceed out
4) Decide to use the cart-horse to try and find a closer location to the new objective, get teleported inside a building model with no doors, and quit momentarily.

Returning with a glass of milk and increased determination, I tried again. This time, I didn't let those roving bands of bandits stand for... standing there and attacking bystanders(!) and engaged in combat with them! I quickly found myself standing upon my enemy's shoulders, slashing at him, and him at me, and, unfortunately, quickly fell. The following proceeded to happen:

1) I reloaded my last save game, however, the objective marker was now moving in an inversely proportional direction and behavior to the mouse cursor.
2) A second music track began playing on top of the other.
3) Mouse became unfixed, and the hotkey to fix it stopped working.
4) Could no longer interact with any civillian NPCs
5) Bandits refused to chase. They could attack, but as far as taking a step is concerned, they were done with that.

So, broken, boring, and ugly. Don't buy this. Sorry, dev, but, as I assume, this is probably your first game, and you should really work to make something better than this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh man. This game is terrible. It's a pretty hilarious game though to be honest, I would definitely recommend it as a game to Ƒuck around with if you're bored with friends and only if you get it for free. For me alone, I got a really good laugh out of it and because it was free for me, I definitely thought it was worth my time. I was laughing non-stop. At the ṡhitty graphics. At the terrible controls and how difficult it is to interact with anything in the entire 'vast' world. The enemies are horrendously programmed and glitch and I moonwalked all over them and jumped on top of clans of bandits.

The world is pretty small but fun to run around in and look at the stupid ṡhit that's all over. The movement is very slow and amusing in some situations. (Like to climb up some steps that lead to some useless balcony in a mine, you have to jump up the steps like four at a time. It's things like this that made the game so quirky) The combat is very clunky and not fluid at all. Every hit feels like you're tied to a ball and chain stuck on the bottom level of an ocean. Another noteworthy mention of the game is a hilarious event that occured. There is a strange house in the middle of nowhere with what seems to be a prison door to a moderately sized house and once entered you just kind of teleport to the bottom of some mining area. Good lightning and some creepy sounds down there as well as finding motherƒucking 50 APPLES! in one chest make for another ƒucking hilarious experience.

The music is actually decent considering how bad the rest of the game is. A lot of the NPCs and models look pretty funny. More good things to laugh at. Also you can pick dozens and dozens of apples for some reason. Like.. they're everywhere. I saw others were leaving it running just for the trading cards as well as a few of my friends and after seeing it I could tell it was one of those games (kind of like those movies) where it's so bad it's kind of funny and that's what I personally think of this game.

It's like a hour of a free comedy movie better than most I see now adays. I definitely would not recommend buying it to support it for it's after-alpha stage as I'm sure almost anyone can see this is and will stay a piece of garbage. I suppose though it's comedic value pays off your time if you can get the game for free. Overall, I found it an enjoyable hilariously terrrible experience.

I worry about the well-fare of developers like this. I can understand your dream, you 19 year old, you, but at this point I feel like flat-out development is beyond reach for you. I don't mean to not keep trying, but maybe consider getting better before you release something for real money on the market.

As for the rest of you, and the developer, I suppose, if he reads through this, this is my experience with the game:

I spawned in a jail-cell without context. It looked... meh, about on par with a vanilla, original release, Mount and Blade. I worked through it, finding, to my surprise that everything worked, with some minor inconveneince as I discovered that chains came with a forcefield. No worries, I suppose that it *is* in an alpha build, and collision boxes will possibly be refined.

So, once out of that, I immediately began grabbing all of the things, which is where things began going wrong, the ability to pick things up breaking after a moment and never being able to be used again with exception to the rusty sword and shield.

I was then engaged in intense, mortal combat with the nearest enemy, and at first, I thought I couldn't attack, possibly because I was out of stamina, which never seems to regenerate. However, it was just that the animation for attacks rarely plays, and I was actually doing damage- sometimes. Anyway, I ran around the camp, the enemy not able to deal with my combat prowress as it chased after me, and, finding it empty, I ran on to the first location.

While exploring the land, I found the following wonders:

1) A pig model with no pig AI
2) A completely empty village
3) Armies of clones of a man who seemed to enjoy wearing a  skull
4) A pond that allowed any mortal man to ascend to the level of Jesus, and walk upon it's pure, blue, surfaces
5) A deer that can do the same
6) Sudden day-night cycles, with night doing nothing to change the ambient light levels, and lasting a fraction of the the day.

So, I finally reached our first objective, the walled city of Completely-forgettable, and proceeded to do the following things:

1) Push the horse cart around, because it's model is apparently not fixed and you can just push it around as muchas you want
2) Hire an underling to discover that the command system does not work.
3) Talk to the commander, get a new mission, and proceed out
4) Decide to use the cart-horse to try and find a closer location to the new objective, get teleported inside a building model with no doors, and quit momentarily.

Returning with a glass of milk and increased determination, I tried again. This time, I didn't let those roving bands of bandits stand for... standing there and attacking bystanders(!) and engaged in combat with them! I quickly found myself standing upon my enemy's shoulders, slashing at him, and him at me, and, unfortunately, quickly fell. The following proceeded to happen:

1) I reloaded my last save game, however, the objective marker was now moving in an inversely proportional direction and behavior to the mouse cursor.
2) A second music track began playing on top of the other.
3) Mouse became unfixed, and the hotkey to fix it stopped working.
4) Could no longer interact with any civillian NPCs
5) Bandits refused to chase. They could attack, but as far as taking a step is concerned, they were done with that.

So, broken, boring, and ugly. Don't buy this. Sorry, dev, but, as I assume, this is probably your first game, and you should really work to make something better than this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh man. This game is terrible. It's a pretty hilarious game though to be honest, I would definitely recommend it as a game to Ƒuck around with if you're bored with friends and only if you get it for free. For me alone, I got a really good laugh out of it and because it was free for me, I definitely thought it was worth my time. I was laughing non-stop. At the ṡhitty graphics. At the terrible controls and how difficult it is to interact with anything in the entire 'vast' world. The enemies are horrendously programmed and glitch and I moonwalked all over them and jumped on top of clans of bandits.

The world is pretty small but fun to run around in and look at the stupid ṡhit that's all over. The movement is very slow and amusing in some situations. (Like to climb up some steps that lead to some useless balcony in a mine, you have to jump up the steps like four at a time. It's things like this that made the game so quirky) The combat is very clunky and not fluid at all. Every hit feels like you're tied to a ball and chain stuck on the bottom level of an ocean. Another noteworthy mention of the game is a hilarious event that occured. There is a strange house in the middle of nowhere with what seems to be a prison door to a moderately sized house and once entered you just kind of teleport to the bottom of some mining area. Good lightning and some creepy sounds down there as well as finding motherƒucking 50 APPLES! in one chest make for another ƒucking hilarious experience.

The music is actually decent considering how bad the rest of the game is. A lot of the NPCs and models look pretty funny. More good things to laugh at. Also you can pick dozens and dozens of apples for some reason. Like.. they're everywhere. I saw others were leaving it running just for the trading cards as well as a few of my friends and after seeing it I could tell it was one of those games (kind of like those movies) where it's so bad it's kind of funny and that's what I personally think of this game.

It's like a hour of a free comedy movie better than most I see now adays. I definitely would not recommend buying it to support it for it's after-alpha stage as I'm sure almost anyone can see this is and will stay a piece of garbage. I suppose though it's comedic value pays off your time if you can get the game for free. Overall, I found it an enjoyable hilariously terrrible experience.

Disclaimer: I think I got this game via an indiegala giveaway. I can’t remember having paid for it (Thank Cthulhu!)

Note: I didn’t manage to play this game for the reasons below. That means that I couldn’t progress much let alone completing it. I gave up after an hour and a half of honest tries to get to the first major quest.
I tried both (opposite) directions the quest marker pointed towards and ended up frustrated because the invisible walls that blocked me to get to my goal. Then I died … somehow.

So this game has some huge technical issues:
-	Day and night switch within seconds. Or meters. I am not quite sure what triggers the changing.
-	Moving doesn’t work: sometimes I get stuck running mode without doing anything.
-	- Oh – I walked on an enemy once. Good times …
-	Combat doesn’t work. My character refuses to swing his sword – unless when there are no enemies around. Than he cuts through the air like a pro.
-	Picking up items works barely. It’s almost pure luck to get what one aims for.
-	There’s no problem with the graphics being bad. It’s indie and early access after all. But the graphics are glitch all over the place.
-	The invisible walls: they are literally everywhere. Everywhere. I couldn’t proceed in the game although trying hard because of them. Hell, I even couldn’t move on the map properly because of them. They are game breaking.
-	Once parts of the menu have been opened, they can’t be closed again. Game breaking again: Never ever open the “controls” part. Don’t do it. EVER!

After the technical issues, let’s look at the game itself:

-	The music: I thought within the first few minutes that it is surprisingly good. Almost moody. Than it started to bother me as the only two tracks were just the same 40 or so seconds of music looping and looping and looping and looping and – you get the idea.
-	I like to model my character. Unfortunately, there’s no such option.
-	I like story in games. Unfortunately, there is no.
-	I like beautiful or at least somehow interesting environments. There are no. just grass and hills and grey stuff that might be roads (I guess?). Unfortunately.

This can’t be considered an early access game. It is not ready for early access or any public in the first place. It is not even a tech demo or anything of this sort. It is just a broken piece of software.

How does one even begin to recommend the perfect game? This question has been inside my head, thriving and distracting, ever since I first experienced Blood of Old.

It is a delicate, painstaking idea of a process that has intimidated and belittled me for the past week or two. I sit at my PC, but before I can even begin to type, a loud, wet-sounding voice in the base of my skull reminds me that I am not worthy and I never will be. Discouraged, alone and unwanted, I drink myself to sleep and hope that tomorrow I awake as a new person, one capable of successfully tackling this challenge, this feat, this impossible task. This has been my nightly routine since Thanksgiving, the day a download code for the game mysteriously came packaged with my new body pillow.

Now I am a man anew. The New Year has arrived, and with it, it has bought a new feeling of capability and determination. Scotch in hand, one-handed ergonomic keyboard in the other, I have no doubt in my mind that I can at least make an attempt to describe Blood of Old.

Blood of Old is not a game about knights. It is not a game about combat, a game about monsters, a game about gold. I can not stress that enough, Blood of Old is not a game about gold. Blood of Old is a game about you. You, the player. I, the player. We; Us. Us all. Them. All of us. Every person. Human kind. We, the players. You and I, everyone you know. Everyone I know. Early Access Review

In my whopping thirty minutes of playtime I escaped a prison and ran to a town.  During such events I fought one guy, getting a little motion sick as I did.  I hit an invisible wall in route to town, Bearglove or something.  Then noticed that there were two waypoint markers directing me in two different directions.  So I opted for the one that was behind me, made it to the town and found the Commander as per my mission.  I asked him for a job, he offered me one, and I told him I couldn't right now.  Fin.

I'm giving this a thumbs up because of promise.  I can see what can be done and I hope to see it become something fun.  Right now it is its earliest of alphas.  I'd like to see combat and all-over user interface enhancements and a better mission logging.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review states what is in the game as of June 25th, 2015 and is outdated. The game has changed since then.	However, the edit to the TL;DR was made Feb 7th 2016

I have little playtime, but what I've seen has amazing potential.  Right off the bat, the menu screens are well polished (for an alpha, and I'm sure it will be beautiful when the game is finished), and they have amazing music. It is very driving. Now, since the game is very early in development, is is poorly optimized, and may tank some systems. The gameplay itsself is hardly riveting. Keep in mind that it is currently more a tech demo than a full game. There is currently no story, just tasks. I have little experience with combat, but from what I have seen it will be nice. The sounds are in place, but enemies don't do damage. A small issue I have with the combat is that your enemies and you can clip through each other, making combat difficult as you can easily get flanked.

Some bugs/Glitches   (for the devs)
Combat, as said earlier,
The crosshairs. It's not where your character is looking,
Camera angle. This ties in with the crosshairs, and it makes it difficult to see sometimes.
Pros and cons  Pros
+ Good sounds
+ Active devs and community
Cons
- Placeholder graphics
- Poor camera
- Sword and shields are rusty (combat clipping)
- Poorly Optimized

TL;DR
The game's an alpha that literally just released on Steam. Wait a few months, It'll be worth the price. Especially now with the release sale.
EDIT It's your opinion. However, I can say that it is being updated, but very slowly.
